title: Opinion: Jim Harbaugh finally gets Michigan on track in demolition of Notre Dame
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: USA TODAY Sports' Paul Myerberg provides his opinion of the top three programs in the history of college football. USA TODAY

Jim Harbaugh needed this. His team needed this, too. But Harbaugh needed it more.

To remind his players what this feels like. To remind himself what it feels like. When the defense swarms and the offense rolls and the 100,000-plus fans in the stadium roar.

It has been a while, no?

Been a while since Harbaugh’s Michigan Wolverines took the field against a top-10 team and throttled them. No, demoralized them.

That was easy to see Saturday night under the lights, when the rain finally lifted, and Notre Dame’s shoulders began to sag in No. 20 Michigan's 45-14 demolition. And by the time senior running back Tru Wilson took a handoff, cut to his left, and scooted 27 yards for a touchdown, it was all over but the dancing.

Not that Michigan fans dance much. But for the first time in a few years, no one would’ve blamed them.

Michigan coach Jim Harbaugh watches the action during Saturday's game against Notre Dame. (Photo: Kirthmon F. Dozier, Detroit Free Press)

Now, maybe the No. 7 Fighting Irish aren’t that good. They arrived in Ann Arbor with a 5-1 record, a loss to Georgia and a narrow win over middling USC in their game two weeks ago.

Still, they were a top-10 team. A playoff team a year ago. A roster built on top-flight recruiting classes and several future pros.

So …

… yeah, Michigan took the field against a team of equal — or near equal — talent and blitzed it. The defense played a lot like it did in the second half at Beaver Stadium last Saturday, when Penn State kept getting the ball and punting it after three downs.

This Saturday night, the Fighting Irish punted nine times — nine. They rushed for 47 yards. Passed for 133. This is a team that had averaged close to 450 yards a game.

Again, it’s fair to wonder about Notre Dame’s schedule.

It’s not fair to wonder about Michigan's mental toughness.

Not anymore. Not this group.

FOOTBALL FOUR: Alabama and LSU on collision course

MICHIGAN: Used five-man sledgehammer to take down No. 7 Notre Dame

OHIO STATE: Big-time players have Buckeyes looking like a No. 1 team

A week ago, this same team found its way from a 21-point hole in the first half in State College. It came up a play short in the end when Ronnie Bell dropped a pass in the end zone.

The sophomore receiver stood on the sideline in damn near shock as Penn State iced the game. Several of his teammates met with reporters after the game carrying similar expressions.

And yet … underneath the disappointment you could tell the team thought it had found something. Harbaugh sounded optimistic, even considering the brutal nature of the loss.

You can argue the team found it too late. And it might be, if all that matters is a Big Ten title.

But he’s trying to reboot a program, too.

Harbaugh made a lot of change this offseason and has been searching for ways to push his team to the top of the conference. For a while, his team looked stuck between all of the change.

Not against Notre Dame. Not in the rain. Not when Michigan knew it would have to line up and control the line of scrimmage.

Speed and space may sound nice, but it doesn’t work so well in the rain.

Blocking and tackling do. As does running the football, which the Wolverines did all game.

Michigan ran for 303 yards, led by Hassan Haskins and Zach Charbonnet. They ran through holes as wide as the stadium, and when they met defenders in the secondary, they ran over them.

Or leapt over them.

Or stiff-armed them, as Haskins did on a 49-yard run in the third quarter after Notre Dame had cut the lead to 10. His burst up the middle set up a Shea Patterson touchdown pass to Donovan Peoples-Jones, and whatever hope the Fighting Irish had was gone.

For the first time all season, and maybe the first time in a couple of years, the Wolverines took the field against a respectable opponent and played with the kind of force Harbaugh’s best teams used to do.

Yes, maybe it came a week too late. Maybe if they came out a week ago the same way they did Saturday, we’d be having a different conversation.

Yet progress is still worth something, right? Because Harbaugh’s program finally showed some.

All it took was a little rain and a lot of attitude.

description: Michigan football finally gives fans a chance to believe and dance as Jim Harbaugh gets the offense going in the 45-14 rout of Notre Dame.
